GLOSSARY 
 
Ancestral  –  Areas generally belonging to indigenous peoples, comprising lands, inland 
domain  waters, coastal areas, and natural resources therein, held under a claim of 
ownership,  occupied  or  possessed  by  the  indigenous  peoples,  by 
themselves  or  through  their  ancestors,  communally  or  individually, 
continuously to the present except when interrupted by war, force majeure, 
or  displacement  by  force,  deceit,  stealth,  or  as  a  consequence  of 
government  projects  or  any  other  voluntary  dealings  entered  into  by 
government and private individuals and/or corporations, and which are 
necessary to ensure their economic, social, and cultural welfare. It shall 
include ancestral lands, forests, pasture, residential, agricultural, and other 
lands individually owned whether alienable and disposable or otherwise, 
hunting grounds, burial grounds, worship areas, bodies of water, mineral 
and other natural resources, and lands which may no longer be exclusively 
occupied  by  indigenous  peoples  but  from  which  they  traditionally  had 
access to for their subsistence and traditional activities, particularly the 
home ranges of indigenous peoples who are still nomadic and/or shifting 
cultivators. 
 
Protected area  –  National  Integrated  Protected  Areas  System  Act  of  1992  defines  a 
protected area to be “identified portions of land and water set aside by 
reasons of their unique physical and biological significance, managed to

enhance  biological  diversity  and  protected  against  destructive  human 
exploitation.” 
 
River basin  –  A river basin is the portion of land drained by a river and its tributaries. It 
encompasses  the  entire  land  surface  dissected  and  drained  by  many 
streams and creeks that flow downhill into one another, and eventually into 
one river. The final destination is an estuary or an ocean. 
 
Watershed  –  A land area drained by a stream or fixed body of water and its tributaries 
having a common outlet for surface runoff. It includes small watersheds 
with an area of 10,000 hectares (ha) or less, medium-scale watersheds of 
more than 10,000 ha up to 50,000 ha, and large watersheds exceeding 
50,000 ha. 
 
Watershed  –  An operational plan developed in a participatory way with all stakeholders 
management  concerned for a defined watershed that recognizes legal tenurial rights and 
plan  defines the uses for land and other resources in the watershed to provide 
desired goods and services without adversely affecting soil, water, and 
other natural resources. It establishes an investment schedule for financial 
and other resource inputs to improve the productivity of the land with a 5-
year rolling program of activities. 
 
Upland  –  Land area located on slopes of more than 18%. 
 
Upper river  –  The upstream portions of a river basin where the headwaters of streams 
basin  and rivers emanate, consisting of lands with moderate to very steep slopes 
and medium-to-high elevations relative to the river basin valley.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan; (ii) a proposed grant from the Climate Change Fund (CCF); (iii) proposed administration of 
a loan from the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD); and (iv) proposed 
administration of a grant from the Global Environment Facility (GEF) to the Republic of the 
Philippines for the Integrated Natural Resources and Environmental Management Project.1  
2.  The project2 will address unsustainable watershed management in four priority river 
basins: (i) the Chico River Basin in the Cordillera Administrative Region, Northern Luzon; (ii) the 
Wahig–Inabanga  River  Basin  on  the  island  of  Bohol;  (iii)  the  Lake  Lanao  Basin  in  the 
Autonomous Region of Muslim Mindanao; and (iv) the Upper Bukidnon River Basin in Bukidnon, 
Northern  Mindanao.  With  particular  focus  on  indigenous  peoples  and  resource-poor 
communities, the project will reduce and reverse degradation of watersheds and associated 
environmental services caused by forest denudation and unsustainable farming practices. It will 
also  provide  incentives  to  local  communities,  local  government  units  (LGUs),  and  the 
Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR) for improving natural resource 
management by generating sufficient and tangible economic benefits. 3 
3.  The project has been designed as a sector loan4 to support the strategic priorities of the 
Philippine Development  Plan  (PDP)  and  the  DENR’s  framework  plan  for  environment  and 
natural resource management in four representative upper river basins (URBs) encompassing 
23 watersheds.5,6 The project will promote the adoption of ecosystem-based management in 
these URBs; support the rehabilitation, restoration, and protection of degraded forest areas in 
the component watersheds; and support community-based livelihood measures in 1.13 million 
hectares of upland areas with an estimated population of 2.7 million. Approximately 220,000 
household beneficiaries in 9 provinces are targeted. The project supports ADB’s commitment to 
environmentally sustainable growth and inclusive economic growth under Strategy 2020, and is 
in line with ADB’s operational emphasis on sound environmental management. 7  
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
4.  The watersheds of the URBs comprise an estimated 45% of the country’s total land 
area, and are home to one in four Filipinos.8 Natural resources in URBs are the primary source 
for domestic energy and the local production base. These forest ecosystems play a critical role 
in  economic  development  by  regulating  water  quantity  and  quality  for  sustaining  national

2  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) provided project preparatory assistance. ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance to 
the Republic of the Philippines for the Integrated Natural Resources and Environmental Management Sector 
Development Program. Manila.  
3  Mechanisms to achieve these project objectives include (i) payments for environmental services including water 
regulation, soil conservation, carbon offsets, and biodiversity; (ii) income generation from sustainable use and

4  Sector lending is particularly appropriate in this instance as (i) a large number of subprojects are to be financed as 
part of the assistance, and (ii) the assistance is aimed at improving sector policies and institutional capacities. 
5  National Economic and Development Authority. 2011. Philippine Development Plan, 2011–2016. (Chapter 10: 
Conservation, Protection, and Rehabilitation of the Environment and Natural Resources). Pasig. 
6  Four of the 23 watersheds—one from each of the URBs—have been selected as representative subprojects:

and Bubong in Lake Lanao.

2  
irrigation  systems,  hydropower  generation,  and  domestic  water  supplies;  maintaining  and 
restoring biodiversity; and mitigating climate change through carbon sequestration.  
5.  The number of critical watersheds suffering from a loss of watershed integrity9 in the 
URBs increased from 85 in 1995 to 149 in 2007, with a corresponding increase in area from 
3.30  million  hectares  (ha)  to  3.89  million  ha. 10  Steadily  growing  population  pressure, 
displacement  of  marginal  and  indigenous  peoples,  and  inadequate  legal  and  practical 
mechanisms for resource protection has strongly contributed to conversion of forest land into 
marginal upland farming.11 In the four URBs, the resultant annual cost of productivity loss from 
erosion  is  currently  $49  million,  or  about  25%  of  the  national  total.  The  seasonality  of 
production,  with  low  cropping  intensities  and  levels  of  diversification,  has  led  to  high 
unemployment (estimated at 7.1% in October 2010) and underemployment (18.5% in July 2010) 
for  the  poor  (footnote  2).  Deforestation  has  also  rendered  many  poor  communities  more 
vulnerable to natural calamities such as typhoons, flash floods, and landslides.12 
6.  Siltation of rivers and lake systems in Lake Lanao and Upper Bukidnon URBs has 
caused losses in power output estimated at over 50%, with lost revenues for the National Power 
Corporation (NPC) totaling around $66 million annually.13 Siltation of coral reefs and destruction 
of mangroves has also reduced artisanal fish catches, a key source of income and protein for 
poor  coastal  communities.  Degradation  and  overexploitation  of  watersheds  is  a  major 
contributor to increasing poverty, inequitable access to resources and services, and loss of 
livelihood among upland dwellers. Poverty incidence in the project sites (2009) ranges from 
35.8% in Chico to 48.3% in Wahig–Inabanga, significantly higher than the national poverty 
incidence  of  26.5%  in  2009.14 Indigenous  peoples  groups15 and  other  ethnic  minorities 
constitute around 74% of the population in headwaters of the river basins.16 
7.  Policy and institutional relevance. The project fully supports the Government of the 
Philippines’ poverty reduction, watershed management, biodiversity conservation, and climate 
change policy objectives. The project design and scope are directly aligned with the PDP’s aim 
to  use  integrated  ecosystem  management  as  a  major  strategy  for  (i)  sustainably  utilizing 
resources in critical watersheds, (ii) sustainably managing forestlands and ancestral domains for 
enhanced carbon stock, reduced greenhouse gas emissions, and (iii) adapting to different 
climate change scenarios. 
8.  In line with the DENR's program mandate, the project supports current institutional 
programs  and  policy  directions:  (i)  Joint  Memorandum  Circular  Number  1,  Series  of  2010 
between the Department of Agriculture (DA), the Department of Agrarian Reform, and the 
DENR adopts a convergence initiative to strengthen the development framework for sustainable

rural  development  and  espouses  watershed-based  ecosystem  management  to  reinforce 
interventions between the three agencies;17 (ii) Executive Order 23, Series of 2011 declares a 
moratorium on the cutting and harvesting of timber in natural and residual forests; and (iii) 
Executive Order 26, Series of 2011 or the National Greening Program, attempts to consolidate 
and harmonize all greening initiatives of  the government, civil society, and the private sector.  
9.  Phased  Devolution. The project is consistent with the national policy of devolving 
specified environmental and natural resources management functions and responsibilities to 
local governments, as expressed in the Republic Act 7160 or the Local Government Code 
(1991), the recognition of indigenous peoples rights to their ancestral domains (Republic Act 
8371), and the adoption of community-based forest management as the main strategy for 
sustainable  forest  management  (Executive  Order  263).  The  project  will  address 
institutional/policy  gaps  at  the  national  and  local  levels  by:  (i)  reinforcing  existing  co-
management policies18 between DENR and LGU clusters as part of Comprehensive Land Use 
Plans  (CLUPs);  (ii)  establishing  LGU  ordinances  for  conservation  through  user  fees  and 
investment  agreements  over  LGU  managed  forest  lands;  and  (iii)  establishing  plow-back 
mechanisms  for  conservation  investments  in  protected  areas  and  ancestral  domains  from 
creation  of  new  productive  assets,  private  sector  investments,  and  deploying  payment  for 
environmental services (PES). 
 
10.  External support, lessons learned, and other linked projects. The project design is 
based on more than 30 years of experience in watershed management in the Philippines, from 
the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)–IFAD  cofinanced  Highland  Agricultural  Development 
Project, which was initiated in the Cordillera Administrative Region in 1986, through to the 
Cordillera Highland Agricultural Resource Management Project19 implemented from 1997 to 
2004. Lessons learned from these projects, as well as recent experiences from the Southern 
Philippines Irrigation Sector Project,20 are incorporated in the project design to address the 
conflict between agricultural production and natural resource protection in watersheds. The 
integrated project also draws on implementation lessons from the ongoing Integrated Coastal 
Resources Management Project21 and the Infrastructure for Rural Productivity Enhancement 
Sector Project22 to avoid delays in the activity schedule and allow appropriate lead times for 
LGU and community consultation and preparation.23 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The  project  impact  will  be  improved  condition  of  watersheds  generating  livelihood 
benefits in the four URBs. The outcome of the project will be increased rural household incomes 
and LGU revenues in selected watersheds in the four URBs. 
12.  Consistent with the sector modality, project outcomes will be influenced through policy 
dialogue to (i) clarify, rationalize, and delineate use rights of local communities and indigenous

peoples as part of watershed management regimes; and (ii) enable LGUs to establish model 
contracts and supportive local ordinances to implement watershed management plans. LGU 
experience  with  enterprise  management  will  be  adapted  to  manage  watershed  resources 
identified for production.  
13.  The project will initiate interventions in the Lake Lanao, Upper Bukidnon, and Wahig–
Inabanga URBs that will contribute to reducing nutrient runoff from agricultural lands through 
improving  farming  practices  to  reduce  siltation  and  discharge  of  harmful  pollutants  that 
contribute to oxygen depletion in coastal waters of Iligan Bay, Macajalar Bay, and the Bohol 
Sea. This "ridge to reef" approach will support activities under the Coral Triangle Initiative.24 
C.  Outputs 
14.  The project outputs are consolidated based on extensive consultations with stakeholders 
and intended beneficiaries. 
15.  Output  1:  River  basin  and  watershed  management  and  investment  plans 
established. Indicative development plans (IDPs) will be developed for the four URBs to be 
adopted by regional development councils and/or provincial legislative councils. IDPs will be 
based  on  land  capability  assessments  and  participatory  land  use  classification  to  identify 
appropriate management zones, and will be drawn up by the regional and provincial offices of 
the DENR in coordination with national agencies and LGUs. Watershed management plans 
(WMPs) will be prepared for the selected watersheds based on the IDPs. The WMPs will define 
and prioritize subprojects and establish a work program for implementation by LGU clusters and 
municipal development councils. The WMPs will take account of existing tenurial arrangements 
and treat ancestral domains as management subunits.25 A geographical information system 
(GIS) based database for performance monitoring will be established. 
16.  Output 2: Smallholder and institutional investments in conservation increased and 
URB  productivity  enhanced  in  the  forestry,  agriculture  and  rural  sectors.  Subproject 
investments will be undertaken within the 23 project watersheds based on outputs from river 
basin-wide  planning  (output  1).  Interventions  for  watershed  restoration  and  rehabilitation 
covering more than 325,590 ha will be implemented by the DENR to include community-based 
protection,  reforestation  and/or  assisted  natural  regeneration,  production  forestry  including 
demonstrations  on  agroforestry  and  commercial  plantations,  and  conservation  farming. 
Livelihood  improvement  investments  to  be  undertaken  by  municipal  LGUs  include  (i)  645 
kilometers of rural access roads and foot trails; (ii) communal irrigation systems servicing 3,040 
ha; (iii) 275 units of potable community water facilities; (iv) a provincial trading and processing 
center supporting farming communities; and (v) seed funds for replication and/or expansion of 
tested and mature farming technologies. 
17.  Output  3:  River  basin  and  watershed  management  capacity  and  related 
governance  mechanisms  strengthened.  The  project  will  (i)  assist  LGUs  to  establish 
operational clusters at watershed and river basin levels; (ii) train LGUs and local community 
organizations on land resource assessments, land use planning, and watershed management 
and  monitoring;  (iii)  provide  support  for  technical  extension-information,  education  and 
communication; (iv) capacitate LGUs in carbon stock enhancement and land management 
practices to reduce carbon dioxide emissions and land-based pollution, and (v) support the 
establishment of community watershed protection brigades.

18.  Output 4: Project management and support services delivered. The project will 
support the establishment of a national project coordination office (NPCO), regional project 
coordinating offices (RPCO), provincial project management offices (PPMO) and watershed 
management  and  project  coordination  offices  (WMPCO)  at  the  DENR.  The  NPCO  will  (i) 
coordinate  consultant  recruitment  and  supervision;  (ii)  conduct  procurement  of  materials, 
equipment, and vehicles during project implementation; (iii) operationalize the project monitoring 
and evaluation system; (iv) mobilize resources for capacity building of DENR’s regional and 
provincial units and the LGUs; (v) consolidate the annual program and budgets received from 
provincial and regional levels; and (vi) conduct gender and safeguard monitoring and reporting. 
19.  Special  features:  Climate  Change  Fund  and  Global  Environment  Facility.  The 
project,  as  supplemented  by  grants,  will  mainstream  climate  change  mitigation  through 
investments for (i) establishing smallholder-based biomass energy forest demonstration plots 
with  private  equity  contribution  in  upper  Bukidnon,  (ii)  establishing  and  verifying  reduced 
emissions from deforestation and forest degradation and conservation and enhancement of 
carbon stocks (REDD+) through demonstration activities, and (iii) implementing appropriate 
climate change adaptation measures in upland production systems. Through GEF, biodiversity 
conservation will be mainstreamed in watersheds through application of a community-based 
biodiversity corridor approach for conservation of remaining mossy forest stands in the Chico–
Agno–Magat River basins triboundary headwaters area of the Cordillera. PES agreements will 
be developed between indigenous people’s organizations and downstream ecosystem-service 
beneficiaries, initially in the triboundary area between three indigenous people’s organization 
and the NPC.26,27  
D.  Investment and Financing Plans 
20.  The project is estimated to cost $154.13 million, including contingencies, taxes, and 
duties. The investment plan is in Table 1. Detailed cost estimates by expenditure category and 
detailed cost estimates by financier are provided in the project administration manual (PAM).28 
21.  The financing plan is in Table 2. The government, through the DENR, has requested a 
loan of $100 million equivalent from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to help finance the project. 
The loan will have a 20-year term, including a grace period of 8 years, an annual interest rate 
determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending 
facility,29 a commitment charge of 0.15% per annum, and other such terms and conditions set 
forth in the draft financing agreement. Financial charges and interest during implementation will 
be capitalized. 
22.  IFAD will provide a $20 million loan (approximately equivalent to SDR13,250,000) with a 
term of 20 years and a grace period of 5 years. The IFAD loan will carry an interest rate 
equivalent  to  50%  of  the  reference  rate30 for  intermediate  term  loans  for  middle-income 
countries. The IFAD loan will be provided on a parallel basis and partially administered by

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
25.  The implementation period is 7 years to allow for the longer commitment recommended 
for NRM projects. Within each of the URBs, there will be a phased approach to work from one 
watershed to the next, starting with the 4 priority subproject watersheds, until all the URBs are 
covered. As the executing agency, DENR will assume full responsibility in project administration 
and  management.  An  interagency  National  Project  Steering  Committee  (NPSC)  will  be 
established to provide policy guidance chaired by a DENR undersecretary. The National Project 
Coordination Office (NPCO) will be established at the DENR central office with the Forest 
Management Bureau. The Municipal Development Fund Office will administer the funds for rural 
infrastructure improvements to be implemented by the municipal LGUs except for those covered 
by  the  Cordillera  Highland  Agricultural  Resource  Management  project  areas  which  will  be 
administered by the Department of Agriculture. Implementation arrangements are summarized 
in Table 3 and described in detail in the PAM.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Economic and Financial 
26.  Project beneficiaries include local level stakeholders, public utilities and their customers, 
and river basin stakeholders. Beneficiaries will benefit from increased incomes generated from 
providing  rural  infrastructure,  sustainable  forestry  and  agricultural  activities,  and  extension 
services initiated and supported by the project. The project is expected to yield substantial 
benefits: (i) incremental benefits from increased crop yields and productivity through investment 
in  improved  rural  accessibility  and  irrigation,  extension  services,  sustainable  forestry,  and 
agricultural diversification activities; (ii) incremental employment creation estimated at  270,000 
person-months of wage-generating opportunities for households and local communities from 
proposed investments; (iii) households benefiting from safe drinking water, hence avoiding 
significant water-related diseases and health-care-related costs; (iv) improved water quality 
within URBs with reduced operating and delivery costs, bringing about significant benefit for 
public utilities, household enterprises, small and medium-sized enterprises, and downstream 
farmers that utilize water for a variety of purposes; (v) increased economic activity, improved 
service delivery, and greater security from the adverse impacts of climate change and natural 
disasters  benefiting  the  population  within  URBs  and  81  LGUs,  the  majority  of  which  are 
categorized as low-income municipalities; (vi) reduced carbon dioxide emissions and better 
protection and conservation of biodiversity will benefit the population in all URBs and LGUs; (vii) 
improved ecosystem services such as climate regulation, watershed protection, water quality 
regulation,  soil  erosion  prevention,  and  nutrition  retention  realized  by  improved  forest 
ecosystems in the four URBs; and (viii) avoided loss of forest cover, critical in the URBs 
servicing downstream infrastructure.  
27.   Economic  analysis  was  conducted  for  five  sample  investments,  including  (i) 
rehabilitation and improvement of small-scale communal irrigation systems, (ii) rehabilitation 
and improvement of rural access roads, (iii) establishment of communal drinking water supply, 
(iv) establishment of agroforestry plantations, and (v) establishment of plantation forestry. Base-
case economic internal rates of return for the five sample investments are 18.0%, 38%, 34%, 
28%,  and  43.0%  respectively,  demonstrating  the  viability  of  the  packaged  subproject 
investments.33 
B.  Governance 
28.  Procurement of civil works and goods will be carried out in accordance with ADB's 
Procurement  Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time),  while  engagement  of 
consultants will follow ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from 
time to time). Land use assessment planning, zoning, delineation, and demarcation will be 
 
conducted  under  the  direct  supervision  of  the  DENR  and  using  DENR  guidelines. Force 
account procedures will be used for procurement of labor for demarcation and civil works since 
the works are small in scale and in remote locations. These will be undertaken by the DENR 
and/or the LGUs which have the capacity to undertake such works. All civil works contracts 
exceeding $100,000 and less than $5,000,000 will be procured through the national competitive 
bidding procedure (footnote 28). Community participation will be used for forest protection, 
reforestation, assisted natural regeneration, and commercial and agroforestry demonstrations to 
 
ensure sustained benefits. The NPCO shall ensure that all accounts at the DENR-CO and the 
MDFO are consolidated and audited by the Commission on Audit or other auditors acceptable 
to  ADB.  ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  was  explained  to  and 
discussed  with  the  government  and  the  DENR.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and 
supplementary measures are described in the PAM (footnote 28). 
                                                 
33 Economic and financial analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

9 
 
C.  Poverty and Social 
29.  The project targets about 220,000 household beneficiaries, the majority of which are 
vulnerable  and  marginalized.  It  is  recognized  that  the  targeted  local  groups  have  limited 
influence on decision making. A consolidated consultation and participation plan, resettlement 
framework, indigenous peoples planning framework (IPPF), and gender action plan have been 
prepared to ensure that concerns of vulnerable sectors are addressed and benefits equitably 
distributed. The project is classified as effective gender mainstreaming as it is designed to 
benefit  women  by  increasing  their  participation  and  decision  making  in  natural  resource 
management at the community and LGU levels and providing improved access to services. 
D.  Safeguards 
30.  Environment (category B). Project interventions in reforestation and assisted natural 
regeneration and forest protection, and demonstrations in commercial tree plantations and 
agroforestry, will generate positive environmental impacts. These benefits outweigh the minimal 
and temporary adverse impacts, which are easily mitigated by adopting the environmental 
monitoring  and  management  plan  and  observing  additional  environmental  safeguards,  as 
outlined in the environmental assessment and review framework (EARF) covering the four 
summary initial environmental examinations of the sample subprojects, which were prepared to 
comply with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009).34 The EARF will be posted on ADB’s 
website upon Board approval of the Project. 
31.  Involuntary  resettlement  (category  B).  Land  use  zoning  may  result  in  restricted 
access  to  privately  held  ancestral  and/or  communal  properties,  particularly  for  indigenous 
peoples, potentially impacting their sources of food and livelihood. A resettlement framework to 
guide the preparation of resettlement plans for project-affected people has been prepared and 
endorsed  by  the  government,  and  is  consistent  with  relevant  national  laws  and  ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement.35 
32.  Indigenous peoples (category A). An estimated 73.5% of household beneficiaries are 
indigenous peoples and/or ethnic minorities. To guide the preparation of indigenous peoples 
plans, an Indigenous Peoples Planning Framework (IPPF) has been prepared, consistent with 
national laws and legal procedures and ADB’s safeguard policy on indigenous peoples. The 
IPPF has been endorsed by the government.36 Ethnic minorities such as the Maranaos of 
Muslim Mindanao were consulted, and participation and benefit-sharing arrangements are in 
line with the specific provincial and municipal LGU structures and the Autonomous Region for 
Muslim Mindanao Organic Act.

in the risk assessment and risk management plan.37

IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
34.  The government has assured ADB that implementation of the project shall conform to all 
applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures,  safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the PAM 
and loan and grant documents. The government has agreed with ADB on certain covenants for 
the project, which are set forth in the financing agreement for the project. 
35.  The  proposed  loan  will  become  effective  upon  establishment  of  the  initial  project 
organizational units—the NPSC, NPCO, four RPCOs, and at least four PPMOs at the core 
project sites to the satisfaction of ADB. 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
36.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve 
(i)  the loan of $100,000,000 to the Republic of the Philippines for the Integrated 
Natural Resources and Environmental Management Project from ADB’s ordinary 
capital  resources,  with  interest  to  be  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term of 20 
years, including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions 
as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft financing 
agreement presented to the Board; 
(ii)  the grant not exceeding the equivalent of $1,410,000 to the Republic of the 
Philippines  from  ADB’s  Climate  Change  Fund  for  the  Integrated  Natural 
Resources and Environmental Management Project on terms and conditions that 
are  substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft  financing 
agreement presented to the Board; 
(iii)  the  administration  by  ADB  of  the  loan  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
SDR13,250,000 to the Republic of the Philippines for the Integrated Natural 
Resources  and  Environmental  Management  Project,  to  be  provided  by  the 
International Fund for Agricultural Development; and 
(iv)  the  administration  by  ADB  of  the  grant  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of 
$2,500,000  to  the  Republic  of  the  Philippines  for  the  Integrated  Natural 
Resources and Environmental Management Project, to be provided by the Global 
Environment Facility.

River basin  –  A river basin is the portion of land drained by a river and its tributaries. It 
encompasses  the  entire  land  surface  dissected  and  drained  by  many 
streams and creeks that flow downhill into one another, and eventually into 
one river. The final destination is an estuary or an ocean. 
 
Watershed  –  A land area drained by a stream or fixed body of water and its tributaries 
having a common outlet for surface runoff. It includes small watersheds 
with an area of 10,000 hectares (ha) or less, medium-scale watersheds of 
more than 10,000 ha up to 50,000 ha, and large watersheds exceeding 
50,000 ha. 
 
Watershed  –  An operational plan developed in a participatory way with all stakeholders 
management  concerned for a defined watershed that recognizes legal tenurial rights and 
plan  defines the uses for land and other resources in the watershed to provide 
desired goods and services without adversely affecting soil, water, and 
other natural resources. It establishes an investment schedule for financial 
and other resource inputs to improve the productivity of the land with a 5-
year rolling program of activities. 
 
Upland  –  Land area located on slopes of more than 18%. 
 
Upper river  –  The upstream portions of a river basin where the headwaters of streams 
basin  and rivers emanate, consisting of lands with moderate to very steep slopes 
and medium-to-high elevations relative to the river basin valley.
